The gang that dubbed itself “the businessclub” stole 20 to 30 terabytes of data, ran a 200,000 strong botnet army and engaged in espionage across Eastern Europe in addition to robbing banks, stealing credentials and launching ransomware: http://bit.ly/1E9zpT4

Meanwhile, Trend Micro set up a honeypot posing as a gas tank monitoring system, which was quickly hit by a DDoS attack and queried by hackers in Iran and Syria: http://bit.ly/1DvCd1J

And Dell SecureWorks found that a Chinese hacking group dubbed Threat Group 3390, or “Emissary Panda,” compromised approximately 100 organizations in industries including pharmaceuticals, aerospace, and energy.

Scott Walker has called the OPM hack evidence that “we must confront China about its persistent cyberattacks against our government and companies.” Florida Sen. CHRYSLER WAITED 18 MONTHS TO DISCLOSE CYBER VULNERABILITY TO REGULATORS — Fiat Chrysler stayed silent about the cybersecurity flaw in its radios for 18 months before telling federal regulators because “the automaker says it was working on a fix and didn’t consider the problem a safety defect,” Bloomberg reported Wednesday.

“The episode came just days before Fiat Chrysler agreed to a $105 million penalty to settle complaints about its recall performance on other issues and as NHSTA faces its own criticism for failing to promptly get unsafe vehicles off the street.” The story: http://bloom.bg/1UpqCpl
